Entheus crinissus
[ sic ]; Weeks, 1911. Ill. Diurn. Lep. 2 , p. XV.

Autochton crinisus
; Andrade, 2002, in Costa et al . Monogr. Terc. Milenio , Zaragoza, 2 : 158.

Type material.
Papilio crinisus Cramer, 1780
was described based on an unspecified number of specimens from Suriname . A female syntype was found at NBC with the following labels: / Coll. Calkoen/ Museum Leiden/ ♀ /. Aiming to establish the correct identity of the species, this female specimen is hereby designated as the lectotype of
Papilio crinisus
and the following labels will be attached: / Lectotypus / Lectotypus
Papilio crinisus Cramer, 1780 Siewert, Lemes, Mielke & Casagrande
det. 2020/.

Diagnosis. FW length: males 21–25 mm (n=52) and females 24–26 mm (n=9).
Augiades crinisus
resembles
Augiades vespasius vespasius
in the color pattern of wings, but is distinguished by its well-developed hyaline spots on FW. The following combination of genitalic characters differentiates
A. crinisus
from the other
Augiades species
: uncus shorter than in
A. vespasius
; valva with distal margin strongly bifid; lamella antevaginalis bilobed, with margin slightly serrated; lamella postvaginalis entirely sclerotized and broader than in
A. vespasius .
Variation. The hyaline spots on FW are smaller in some specimens from Acre , North Brazil , and the color pattern of the wings is darker in specimens from Fonte Boa, Amazonas, North Brazil .

Immatures. Immatures were recorded on
Lecythis lurida (Miers) S. A. Mori
( Lecythidaceae ) ( Moss 1949 ).

Distribution.
Augiades crinisus
is widely distributed in forested areas of Central and South America, with records from Panama , Colombia , Ecuador , Peru , Bolivia , Venezuela , Trinidad and Tobago , Suriname , French Guiana , and Brazil ( Fig. 5 ).

Taxonomic discussion. During the French occupation of the Netherlands , from 1789 to 1813, many private biological collections disappeared.At that time, Joan Calkoen gathered a significant number of specimens from several collections, and recovered many type specimens, including several from Cramer. After his death (in 1812), his collection was sold by his widow in 1814 and a large part of it was incorporated into the NBC, along with a catalog written by Calkoen himself where it is stated that he had some specimens that were described by Stoll and Cramer ( de Jong 2005 ). After examination of the material of the NBC collection, one female specimen that corresponds to the type series of
P. crinisus
was located, making the designation of a lectotype possible.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1 . Species of
Augiades
in dorsal and ventral views. A–D.
A. crinisus
: (A–B) male (Brazil, Bahia, Camacan, Reserva Serra Bonita, DZ 46.026), (C–D) female (Brazil, Amazonas, Fonte Boa, ex coll. Emery, DZ 46.059). E–J.
A. vespasius vespasius
: (E–F) neotype male (Brazil, Espírito Santo, Linhares, DZ 45.497), (G–H) female (Brazil, Espírito Santo, Linhares, DZ 45.567), (I–J) female variety (Brazil, São Paulo, Teodoro Sampaio, Parque Estadual Morro do Diabo). K–N.
A. vespasius bicolor
: (K–L) male (Brazil, Roraima, 10 km E. Boa Vista, DZ 45.676), (M–N) female (Brazil, Amazonas, Barcelos, Rio Aracá, Foz do Rio Curuduri, DZ 40.772).
